text: well I I mean I think if if if spiritual
enlightenment was only open to the rich
the rich would be hopefully a lot better
people than they are um so I don't think
they're necessarily linked um but I
think you know I I I have people ask me
a lot of the time questions along the
lines of you know how can I possibly I
can't to do what you did I can't afford
to go and take a year off from my work
from my family from my obligations from
the contracts the social contracts that
I have with people or the illness that
I'm taking care of or you know whatever
the things are that hold people into the
places um where they're staying you know
um and and and they say I can't afford
to do that in any way in any definition
of the word afford you know um so how
can I have the experiences that you had
and I I think it would be insulting for
me to walk around telling people that
they could do that you know um because
the reality is that even in my life
which has been a life that's that's I've
got a lot of freedom I don't have
children um I've been lucky enough to
have a career that facilitates travel uh
you know I'm healthy even in my life
there was only one moment when I could
have done that and it was that year I
couldn't do it now you know um I'm I'm
way too entrenched in in the lives of
people around me to do it again um and
you know and and and I have one of the
freest schedules of anybody on Earth you
know so so it's and I also don't think
everybody should do that you know um I I
I or I have a friend one of my favorite
moments before I left on this trip this
editor friend of mine in New York said
to me um wow you're going to an asham
for four months to meditate there's a
part of me that so wishes that I wanted
to do that but I really really have no
desire for it whatsoever you know he's
got to find his way and a different path
but I do think there are people who long
for that um and and all I can think of
is that
you know if the only people who had
spiritual enlightenment available to
them are those who could afford a plane
ticket to India the world would be an
even more unfair place than it already
is um and the example that I always
think of is this this friend of mine
from high school um actually he was my
prom date who's in prison now um as my
mom predicted at the time but anyway he
he's having the
spiritual experience of a lifetime
because he's using that time um to to
focus on meditation and contemplation
and self transformation um and he's in
an 8 by8 foot room uh where every minute
of his day is sort of organized by other
people I would argue that it's probably
easier to find time to meditate in
prison than it is if you have two little
kids at home you know and and you're
also sort of holding down a job and
struggling with a lot of other issues um
but I I have to believe because it would
warp too much my understanding of
humanity that questions of divinity are
available to anybody um and that the
entrance to those questions are
everywhere um and and certainly evidence
shows that you know people have
Transcendent religious experiences in
refugee camps they have them in traffic
jams they have them during war they have
them at their offices you know these
invitations um arrive in people's lives
wherever they are and uh I was lucky
enough um for a lot of reasons to be
able to carve out this huge period of
time to go to this very special place
and do this war um in a really organized
way but my spiritual practices today you
know in my life in New Jersey are
nothing compared to a lot of people I
know who have much busier lives than me
um who insist on making time for this
you know they wake up at 4 o'clock in
the morning and they hold that time
sacred and they they work at it and they
meditate and they didn't have any of the
advantages that I have and they are way
way way closer to the destination that I
was seeking um merely on account of the
fact that they're demanding it whether
they live in Queens or you know Indian
um so
